contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | color = {{taxobox color|fungi}} | name = Nucleariids | image = Nuclearia sp Nikko.jpg | image_caption = ''Nuclearia thermophila'' | domain = [[Eukarya]] | unranked_phylum = [[Opisthokont]]s | ordo = '''Nucleariida''' }} The '''nucleariids''' are a group of [[amoeboid|amoeba]]e<ref>{{cite pmid|11411837}}</ref> with filose [[pseudopod]]s, known mostly from soils and freshwater. They are distinguished from the superficially similar [[vampyrellid]]s mainly by having [[mitochondrion|mitochondria]] with discoid [[crista]]e. ==Classification== {{stem group kingdoms|align=left}} {{-}} Nucleariids are [[opisthokont]]s,<ref name="pmid19157810">{{cite journal |author=Yoshida M, Nakayama T, Inouye I |title=Nuclearia thermophila sp. nov. (Nucleariidae), a new nucleariid species isolated from Yunoko Lake in Nikko (Japan) |journal=European journal of protistology |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=147–155 |year=2009 |month=January |pmid=19157810 |doi=10.1016/j.ejop.2008.09.004 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0932-4739(08)00080-1}}</ref> the group which includes [[animal]]s, [[fungus|fungi]] and several smaller groups. Several studies place the nucleariids as a sister group to the fungi.<ref name="Steenkamp2006">{{cite journal | author = Steenkamp, E.T. | coauthors = Wright, J.; Baldauf, S.L. | year = 2006 | title = The Protistan Origins of Animals and Fungi | journal = Molecular Biology and Evolution | volume = 23 | issue = 1 | pages = 93–106 | doi = 10.1093/molbev/msj011 | pmid = 16151185 }}</ref><ref name="tabrizi">{{Cite journal | author = Shalchian-Tabrizi K, Minge MA, Espelund M, ''et al'' | title = Multigene phylogeny of choanozoa and the origin of animals | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 3 | issue = 5 | pages = e2098 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18461162 | pmc = 2346548 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0002098 | url = http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0002098 | postscript = <!--None--> | editor1-last = Aramayo | editor1-first = Rodolfo }}</ref> ==Characteristics== Nucleariids are usually small, up to about 50 μm in size. * ''[[Nuclearia]]''<ref name="pmid19157810"/> and ''[[Micronuclearia]]''. * The other genera, ''[[Rabdiophrys]]'', ''[[Pinaciophora]]'', and ''[[Pompholyxophrys]]'', are freshwater forms with hollow siliceous scales or spines. These were formerly included among the [[heliozoa]] as the Rotosphaerida. According to a 2009 paper, ''[[Fonticula]]'', a cellular [[slime mold]], is an opisthokont and more closely related to ''Nuclearia'' than to fungi.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Phylogeny of the "Forgotten" Cellular Slime Mold, Fonticula alba, Reveals a Key Evolutionary Branch within Opisthokonta | author = Matthew W. Brown, Frederick W. Spiegel and Jeffrey D. Silberman | journal = Molecular Biology and Evolution | year = 2009 | volume = 26 | issue = 12 | pages = 2699–2709 | doi = 10.1093/molbev/msp185 | pmid = 19692665 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Life|Eukaryota}} [[Category:Nucleariids|*]] [[Category:Amoeboids]]
